title: Introduction to Ezra
content:
Background

There was no TV coverage—no newspapers. But heralds were sent to all parts of the kingdom to announce the news. The king had issued an edict allowing the Jews to return from Persia to their homeland.

The first contingent, which consisted of 42,360 people led by Zerubbabel, returned in BC 536. In BC 458, Ezra led another group the long journey back to their homeland, and finally, a third group left Persia under the leadership of Nehemiah in BC 445. The book of Ezra will tell us of the first two returns, and the book of Nehemiah will guide us through the third return.

These are moments in history that capture our attention. Babylon had held the Jewish war captives for 70 years; but in BC 536, Persia, under Cyrus and Darius, overthrew the Babylonians. Cyrus’s decree let the Jewish exiles return home under Zerubbabel to rebuild the temple of their God. By the year of BC 530, the temple foundation was laid.

The book of Ezra will tell us in detail how the work of rebuilding was stopped. The books of Haggai and Zechariah and Malachi relate the inspiration given the Jewish people to finish the building project. Ezra is the main character of this book, and I will explore in detail his work. Enjoy the book and let it stir your spiritual passion.
metaDescription: Explore the Book of Ezra's historical context, the Jewish return from exile under Zerubbabel, and the rebuilding of the Temple in this expert Bible commentary.

entities.name: Ezra
entities.description: A Jewish scribe and priest who led the second group of Jews from Babylon to Jerusalem.

entities.name: Zerubbabel
entities.description: A governor of the Persian Province of Yehud Medinata and the grandson of Jehoiachin, penultimate king of Judah.

entities.name: Nehemiah
entities.description: A central figure in the post-exilic history of the Jews who supervised the rebuilding of Jerusalem.

entities.name: Cyrus the Great
entities.description: Founder of the Achaemenid Empire who issued the decree for the Jews to return to their homeland.

entities.name: Darius I
entities.description: The third King of Kings of the Achaemenid Empire.

entities.name: Babylon
entities.description: The capital city of the Babylonian Empire, where the Jews were held captive.

entities.name: Haggai
entities.description: A Hebrew prophet during the building of the Second Temple in Jerusalem.

entities.name: Zechariah
entities.description: A prophet of the Kingdom of Judah and a contemporary of Haggai.

faq.question: Who led the three groups of Jewish returnees from Persia?
faq.answer: The first group was led by Zerubbabel (BC 536), the second by Ezra (BC 458), and the third by Nehemiah (BC 445).

faq.question: Which Persian king allowed the Jews to return to rebuild the temple?
faq.answer: Cyrus the Great issued the decree allowing the Jewish exiles to return home and rebuild the temple.

faq.question: What is the historical timeline for the Book of Ezra?
faq.answer: The narrative covers the end of the 70-year Babylonian captivity, beginning with the return in BC 536, the laying of the temple foundation in BC 530, and continues through Ezra's return in BC 458.
